Hlevel types

Higher levels of the homotopical structure:

  • Contractible types ($-2$)
  • Propositions ($-1$)
  • Sets ($0$)
  • Groupoids ($1$)

Contractible types

A contractible type is a type such that every element is equal to a point, the center of contraction.


isContr
  : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} (A : Type ‚Ñì)
  --------------
  ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì

isContr A = Œ£ A (Œª a ‚Üí ((x : A) ‚Üí a == x))

Synonym:

Contractible = isContr
is-singleton = isContr
isSingleton  = isContr

If a type is contractible, any of its points is a center of contraction:

allAreCenter
  : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}
  ‚Üí (c‚ÇÅ : A) ‚Üí (f : (x : A) ‚Üí c‚ÇÅ == x)
  ‚Üí (‚àÄ (c‚ÇÇ : A) ‚Üí (‚àÄ (x : A) ‚Üí c‚ÇÇ == x))

allAreCenter c‚ÇÅ f c‚ÇÇ x = sym (f c‚ÇÇ) ¬∑ (f x)

Propositions

A type is a mere proposition if any two inhabitants of the type are equal.

isProp
  : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} (A : Type ‚Ñì) ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì

isProp A = ((x y : A) ‚Üí x == y)

Synonyms:

is-subsingleton = isProp
isSubsingleton  = isProp
is-prop         = isProp

Let‚Äôs stop a bit. So, these propositios, also named ‚Äúmere‚Äù propositions tell us: in a proposition, its elements are connected with each other. Subsinglenton (which is, subset of a singlenton (a unit point set)) is empty or it has the element. Propositions can be seen as equivalent to ùüò or ùüô.

  • Contractible types ‚âÉ ùüô
  • Propositions ‚âÉ (ùüò if it‚Äôs not inhabited or ùüô if it‚Äôs inhabited)

Therefore, we will find a theorem later that says ‚Äúif A is a proposition, and it‚Äôs inhabited then it‚Äôs contractible‚Äù, and it makes sense perfectly.

hProp
  : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} ‚Üí Type (lsuc ‚Ñì)

hProp {‚Ñì} = ‚àë (Type ‚Ñì) isProp

We prove now that the basic type (‚ä•, ‚ä§) are indeed (mere) propositions:

‚ä•-is-prop : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} ‚Üí  isProp (‚ä• ‚Ñì)
‚ä•-is-prop ()

‚ä§-is-prop : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} ‚Üí  isProp (‚ä§ ‚Ñì)
‚ä§-is-prop _ _ = idp

Synonyms:

ùüò-is-prop = ‚ä•-is-prop
ùüô-is-prop = ‚ä§-is-prop

Sets

A type is a set& by definition if any two equalities on the type are equal Sets are types without any higher *dimensional structure, all parallel paths are homotopic and the homotopy is given by a continuous function on the two paths.

isSet
  : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì
isSet A = (x y : A) ‚Üí isProp (x == y)

Synonyms:

is-set = isSet

The type of sets

hSet
  :  ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} ‚Üí Type (lsuc ‚Ñì)

hSet {‚Ñì}= ‚àë (Type ‚Ñì) isSet

Groupoids

isGroupoid
  : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì

isGroupoid A  = (a‚ÇÄ a‚ÇÅ : A) ‚Üí isSet (a‚ÇÄ ‚â° a‚ÇÅ)

Synonyms:

is-groupoid = isGroupoid

Groupoid
  : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} ‚Üí Type (lsuc ‚Ñì)

Groupoid {‚Ñì} = ‚àë (Type ‚Ñì) isGroupoid

HLevel Lemmas

The following lemmas are not exactly in some coherent order. We are planning to fix that. For now, we are only adding lemmas as soon as we need them.

module HLevelLemmas where

For any type, ,

Contractible types are Propositions:

  contrIsProp
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí isContr A
    -----------
    ‚Üí isProp A

  contrIsProp (a , p) x y = ! (p x) ¬∑ p y

  -- Synonyms
  isContr‚ÜíisProp = contrIsProp

To be contractible is itself a proposition.

  contractible-from-inhabited-prop
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí A
    ‚Üí isProp A
    ----------------
    ‚Üí Contractible A

  contractible-from-inhabited-prop a p = (a , p a )

Propositions are Sets:

  propIsSet
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí isProp A
    ----------
    ‚Üí isSet A

  propIsSet {A = A} f a _ p q = lemma p ¬∑ inv (lemma q)
    where
      triang : {y z : A} {p : y == z} ‚Üí (f a y) ¬∑ p == f a z
      triang {y}{p = idp} = inv (¬∑-runit (f a y))

      lemma : {y z : A} (p : y == z) ‚Üí p == ! (f a y) ¬∑ (f a z)
      lemma {y = y}{w} p =
        begin
          p                       ==‚ü® ap (_¬∑ p) (inv (¬∑-linv (f a y))) ‚ü©
          ! (f a y) ¬∑ f a y ¬∑ p   ==‚ü® ¬∑-assoc (! (f a y)) (f a y) p ‚ü©
          ! (f a y) ¬∑ (f a y ¬∑ p) ==‚ü® ap (! (f a y) ¬∑_) triang ‚ü©
          ! (f a y) ¬∑ (f a w)
        ‚àé

Synonyms:

  prop-is-set  = propIsSet
  prop‚Üíset     = propIsSet
  isProp-isSet = propIsSet
  Prop-is-Set  = propIsSet

Propositions are Sets:

  Set-is-Groupoid
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí isSet A
    --------------
    ‚Üí isGroupoid A

  Set-is-Groupoid {A} A-is-set = Œª x y ‚Üí prop-is-set (A-is-set x y)

  is-prop-A+B
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí isProp A ‚Üí isProp B ‚Üí ¬¨ (A √ó B)
    ---------------------------------
    ‚Üí isProp (A + B)

  is-prop-A+B ispropA ispropB ¬¨A√óB (inl x) (inl x‚ÇÅ) = ap inl (ispropA x x‚ÇÅ)
  is-prop-A+B ispropA ispropB ¬¨A√óB (inl x) (inr x‚ÇÅ) = ‚ä•-elim (¬¨A√óB (x , x‚ÇÅ))
  is-prop-A+B ispropA ispropB ¬¨A√óB (inr x) (inl x‚ÇÅ) =  ‚ä•-elim (¬¨A√óB (x‚ÇÅ , x))
  is-prop-A+B ispropA ispropB ¬¨A√óB (inr x) (inr x‚ÇÅ) = ap inr (ispropB x x‚ÇÅ)

Propositions are propositions. This time, please notice the strong use of function extensionality, used twice here.

  propIsProp
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}
    -- (funext : Function-Extensionality)
    -------------------------------------
    ‚Üí isProp (isProp A)

  propIsProp {_}{A} =
    Œª x y ‚Üí funext (Œª a ‚Üí
              funext (Œª b
                ‚Üí propIsSet x a b (x a b) (y a b)))

  prop-is-prop-always = propIsProp
  prop-is-prop        = propIsProp
  prop‚Üíprop           = propIsProp
  isProp-isProp       = propIsProp
  is-prop-is-prop     = propIsProp

The dependent function type to proposition types is itself a proposition.

  isProp-pi
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : A ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    -- (funext : Function-Extensionality)
    ‚Üí ((a : A) ‚Üí isProp (B a))
    --------------------------
    ‚Üí isProp ((a : A) ‚Üí B a)

  isProp-pi props f g = funext Œª a ‚Üí props a (f a) (g a)

  pi-is-prop = isProp-pi
  Œ†-isProp   = isProp-pi
  piIsProp   = isProp-pi

Propositional extensionality, here stated as prop-ext, is a consequence of univalence axiom.

  prop-ext
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A B : Type ‚Ñì}
    -- (ua : Univalence Axiom)
    ‚Üí isProp A
    ‚Üí isProp B
    ‚Üí (A ‚áî B)
    -----------
    ‚Üí A == B

  prop-ext propA propB (f , g) =
    ua (qinv-‚âÉ f (g , (Œª x ‚Üí propB _ _) , (Œª x ‚Üí propA _ _)))

Synomyms:

  props-‚áî-to-== = prop-ext
  ispropA-B     = prop-ext
  propositional-extensionality = prop-ext

  setIsProp
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}
    -----------------
    ‚Üí isProp (isSet A)

  setIsProp {‚Ñì} {A} p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ =
    funext (Œª x ‚Üí
      funext (Œª y ‚Üí
        funext (Œª p ‚Üí
          funext (Œª q ‚Üí propIsSet (p‚ÇÇ x y) p q (p‚ÇÅ x y p q) (p‚ÇÇ x y p q)))))

  set-is-prop = setIsProp
  set‚Üíprop    = setIsProp

The product of propositions is itself a proposition.

  isProp-prod
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí isProp A
    ‚Üí isProp B
    ---------------------
    ‚Üí isProp (A √ó B)

  isProp-prod p q x y = prodByComponents ((p _ _) , (q _ _))

  √ó-is-prop      = isProp-prod
  ispropA√óB      = isProp-prod
  √ó-isProp       = isProp-prod
  prop√óprop‚Üíprop = isProp-prod

  isSet-prod
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí isSet A ‚Üí isSet B
    -------------------
    ‚Üí isSet (A √ó B)

  isSet-prod sa sb (a , b) (c , d) p q = begin
     p
      ==‚ü® inv (prodByCompInverse p) ‚ü©
     prodByComponents (prodComponentwise p)
      ==‚ü® ap prodByComponents (prodByComponents (sa a c _ _ , sb b d _ _)) ‚ü©
     prodByComponents (prodComponentwise q)
      ==‚ü® prodByCompInverse q ‚ü©
     q
    ‚àé

Synomys:

  √ó-is-set      = isSet-prod
  isSetA√óB      = isSet-prod
  √ó-isSet       = isSet-prod
  set√óset‚Üíset   = isSet-prod

  Prop-/-‚â°
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí (P : A ‚Üí hProp {‚Ñì})
    ‚Üí ‚àÄ {a‚ÇÄ a‚ÇÅ} p‚ÇÄ p‚ÇÅ {Œ± : a‚ÇÄ ‚â° a‚ÇÅ}
    ------------------------------
    ‚Üí p‚ÇÄ ‚â° p‚ÇÅ [ (# ‚àò P) / Œ± ]

  Prop-/-‚â° P {a‚ÇÄ} p‚ÇÄ p‚ÇÅ {Œ± = idp} = proj‚ÇÇ (P a‚ÇÄ) p‚ÇÄ p‚ÇÅ

H-levels actually are preserved by products, coproducts, pi-types and sigma-types.

  id-contractible-from-set
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí isSet A
    ‚Üí {a a' : A}
    --------------------------
    ‚Üí a ‚â° a' ‚Üí isContr (a ‚â° a')

  id-contractible-from-set iA {a}{.a} idp
    = idp , Œª q ‚Üí iA a a idp q
  -- This is quite obvious from the hset definition.
  -- But it's nice to spell it out fully.

Lemma 3.11.3: For any type A, isContr A is a mere proposition.

  isContrIsProp
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}
    --------------------
    ‚Üí isProp (isContr A)

  isContrIsProp {_} {A} (a , p) (b , q) =
    Œ£-bycomponents (inv (q a) , isProp-pi (AisSet b) _ q)
      where
        AisSet : isSet A
        AisSet = propIsSet (contrIsProp (a , p))

  BookLemma3113 = isContrIsProp

Lemma 3.3.3 (HoTT-Book):

  lemma333
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí isProp A ‚Üí isProp B
    ‚Üí (A ‚Üí B)  ‚Üí (B ‚Üí A)
    ----------------------
    ‚Üí A ‚âÉ B

  lemma333 iA iB f g = qinv-‚âÉ f (g , gf , fg)
    where
    private
      fg : (f :> g) ‚àº id
      fg a = iA ((f :> g) a) a

      gf : (g :> f) ‚àº id
      gf b = iB ((g :> f) b) b

  BookLemma333 = lemma333

  prop-inhabited-‚âÉùüô

From Exercise 3.5 (HoTT-Book):

  isProp-‚âÉ-isContr
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí isProp A ‚âÉ (A ‚Üí isContr A)

  isProp-‚âÉ-isContr {A = A} =
    lemma333 isProp-isProp (pi-is-prop (Œª a ‚Üí isContrIsProp)) go back
    where
      private
        go : isProp A ‚Üí (A ‚Üí isContr A)
        go iA a = a , Œª a' ‚Üí iA a a'

        back : (A ‚Üí isContr A) ‚Üí isProp A
        back f = Œª a a' ‚Üí (! œÄ‚ÇÇ (f a) a) ¬∑ (œÄ‚ÇÇ (f a) a')

Equivalence of two types is a proposition Moreover, equivalences preserve propositions.

Contractible maps are propositions:

  isContrMapIsProp
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí (f : A ‚Üí B)
    -------------
    ‚Üí isProp (isContrMap f)

  isContrMapIsProp f = pi-is-prop (Œª a ‚Üí isContrIsProp)

  isEquivIsProp
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí (f : A ‚Üí B)
    ‚Üí isProp (isEquiv f)

  isEquivIsProp = isContrMapIsProp

Equality of same-morphism equivalences

  sameEqv

    ‚Üí {Œ± Œ≤ : A ‚âÉ B}
    ‚Üí œÄ‚ÇÅ Œ± == œÄ‚ÇÅ Œ≤
    ---------------
    ‚Üí    Œ± == Œ≤

  sameEqv {Œ± = (f , œÉ)} {(g , œÑ)} p = Œ£-bycomponents (p , (isEquivIsProp g _ œÑ))

  equiv-iff-hprop
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}

    ‚Üí isProp (A ‚âÉ B)

    = sameEqv f‚â°g
    where
    private
      f‚â°g : (œÄ‚ÇÅ ef) ‚â° (œÄ‚ÇÅ eg)

  propEqvIsprop

  propEqvIsprop iA iB p q =

      p

      ua (idtoeqv p)
        ‚â°‚ü® ap ua (equiv-iff-hprop iA iB (idtoeqv p) (idtoeqv q)) ‚ü©
      ua (idtoeqv q)
        ‚â°‚ü® ua-Œ∑ q ‚ü©
      q
     ‚àé

Equivalences preserve propositions

  isProp-‚âÉ
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí (A ‚âÉ B)
    ‚Üí isProp A
    ----------
    ‚Üí isProp B

  isProp-‚âÉ eq prop x y =
    begin
      x                       ==‚ü® inv (lrmap-inverse eq) ‚ü©
      lemap eq ((remap eq) x) ==‚ü® ap (Œª u ‚Üí lemap eq u) (prop _ _) ‚ü©
      lemap eq ((remap eq) y) ==‚ü® lrmap-inverse eq ‚ü©
      y
    ‚àé

  is-set-equiv-to-set
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí A ‚âÉ B
    ‚Üí isSet A
    ---------
    ‚Üí isSet B

  is-set-equiv-to-set {A = A}{B} e iA
    x y  =  isProp-‚âÉ aux (iA (!f x) (!f y))
    where
    private
     f : A ‚Üí B
     f = lemap e

     !f : B ‚Üí A
     !f = remap e

     aux : (remap e x ‚â° remap e y) ‚âÉ (x ‚â° y)
     aux
       = qinv-‚âÉ (Œª p ‚Üí ! (lrmap-inverse e) ¬∑ ap f p ¬∑ lrmap-inverse e)
                ((Œª { idp ‚Üí idp})
                , (Œª { idp ‚Üí H‚ÇÅ})
                , Œª {p ‚Üí iA (!f x) (!f y) _ p})
       where
       H‚ÇÅ : (! lrmap-inverse e ¬∑ idp) ¬∑ lrmap-inverse e {x} == idp
       H‚ÇÅ = begin
         (! lrmap-inverse e ¬∑ idp) ¬∑ lrmap-inverse e
           ‚â°‚ü® ap (Œª w ‚Üí w ¬∑ (lrmap-inverse e)) (! (¬∑-runit _)) ‚ü©
         ! lrmap-inverse e ¬∑ lrmap-inverse e
           ‚â°‚ü® ¬∑-linv (lrmap-inverse e) ‚ü©
         idp
         ‚àé
  equiv-with-a-set-is-set = is-set-equiv-to-set
  ‚âÉ-with-a-set-is-set = is-set-equiv-to-set

Above, we might want to use univalence to rewrite $x ‚â°B y$. Unfortunately, we can not because a universe level matters, at least for now. A first proof would have been saying $x ‚â°A y$ is a mere proposition and since $A ‚âÉ B$, $x ‚â°B y$ is also a mere proposition. So, $B$ is a set. Second proof is construct a term of ‚ÄòisSet B‚Äô by using the inverse function from the equivalence and some path algebra. Not happy with this but it works.

  ‚âÉ-trans-inv
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì} {A B : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí (Œ± : A ‚âÉ B)
    -----------------------------
    ‚Üí ‚âÉ-trans Œ± (‚âÉ-flip Œ±) == A‚âÉA

  ‚âÉ-trans-inv Œ± = sameEqv (
    begin
      œÄ‚ÇÅ (‚âÉ-trans Œ± (‚âÉ-sym Œ±)) ==‚ü® refl _ ‚ü©
      œÄ‚ÇÅ (‚âÉ-sym Œ±) ‚àò œÄ‚ÇÅ Œ±     ==‚ü® funext (rlmap-inverse-h Œ±) ‚ü©
      id
    ‚àé)

The following lemma is telling us, something we should probably knew already: Equivalence of propositions is the same logical equivalence.

  twoprops-to-equiv-‚âÉ-‚áî
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí isProp A
    ‚Üí isProp B
    -------------------
    ‚Üí (A ‚âÉ B) ‚âÉ (A ‚áî B)

  twoprops-to-equiv-‚âÉ-‚áî {A = A} {B} ispropA ispropB  = qinv-‚âÉ f (g , H‚ÇÅ , H‚ÇÇ)
   where
    f : (A ‚âÉ B) ‚Üí (A ‚áî B)
    f e = e ‚àô‚Üí , e ‚àô‚Üê

    g : (A ‚áî B) ‚Üí (A ‚âÉ B)
    g (h‚Üí , h‚Üê) = qinv-‚âÉ h‚Üí (h‚Üê , (Œª b ‚Üí ispropB (h‚Üí (h‚Üê b)) b) , (Œª a ‚Üí ispropA (h‚Üê (h‚Üí a)) a))

    H‚ÇÅ : f ‚àò g ‚àº id
    H‚ÇÅ (h‚Üí , h‚Üê) = idp

    H‚ÇÇ : g ‚àò f ‚àº id
    H‚ÇÇ e =
      begin
        g (e ‚àô‚Üí , e ‚àô‚Üê)
          ==‚ü®‚ü©
        e ‚àô‚Üí , _
          ==‚ü® Œ£-bycomponents (idp , isEquivIsProp (e ‚àô‚Üí) _ _) ‚ü©
        e
      ‚àé

  ‚àë-prop
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : A ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí isProp A
    ‚Üí ((a : A) ‚Üí isProp (B a))
    ------------------------
    ‚Üí isProp (‚àë A B)

  ‚àë-prop {B = B} iA Œª-iB u v
    = pair= (Œ± , Œ≤)
    where
      Œ± : œÄ‚ÇÅ u ‚â° œÄ‚ÇÅ v
      Œ± = iA (œÄ‚ÇÅ u) (œÄ‚ÇÅ v)

      Œ≤ : (œÄ‚ÇÇ u) ‚â° (œÄ‚ÇÇ v) [ B / Œ± ]
      Œ≤ = Œª-iB (œÄ‚ÇÅ v) (tr B Œ± (œÄ‚ÇÇ u)) (œÄ‚ÇÇ v)

  isProp-Œ£ = ‚àë-prop
  isProp-‚àë = ‚àë-prop
  Œ£-prop = ‚àë-prop

  pi-is-set
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : A ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí ((a : A) ‚Üí isSet (B a))
    -------------------------
    ‚Üí isSet (‚àè A B)

  pi-is-set  setBa f g = b
    where
    a : isProp (f ‚àº g)
    a h1 h2 = funext Œª x ‚Üí setBa x (f x) (g x) (h1 x) (h2 x)

    b : isProp (f ‚â° g)
    b = isProp-‚âÉ (‚âÉ-sym eqFunExt) (pi-is-prop Œª a ‚Üí setBa a (f a) (g a))

  ‚àè-set = pi-is-set
  Œ†-set = pi-is-set

The following was a custom version useful to deal with functions with implicit parameters.

  pi-is-prop-implicit
     : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : A ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
     ‚Üí ((a : A) ‚Üí isProp (B a))
     --------------------------
     ‚Üí isProp ({a : A} ‚Üí B a)

  pi-is-prop-implicit {A = A} {B} f = isProp-‚âÉ explicit-‚âÉ-implicit (pi-is-prop f)
    where
     explicit-‚âÉ-implicit
       : ((a : A) ‚Üí B a) ‚âÉ ({a : A} ‚Üí B a)
     explicit-‚âÉ-implicit = qinv-‚âÉ go ((Œª x x‚ÇÅ ‚Üí x) , (Œª x ‚Üí idp) , (Œª x ‚Üí idp))
       where
         go : ((a : A) ‚Üí B a) ‚Üí ({a : A} ‚Üí B a)
         go f {a} = f a

open HLevelLemmas public

postulate
  law-excluded-middle
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì} {P : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí isProp P
    ------------
    ‚Üí P + (¬¨ P)

LEM = law-excluded-middle

and the more general propositions-as-types formulation of the law of excluded middle is:

postulate
 LEM‚àû
   : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}
   ‚Üí A + (¬¨ A)

law-double-negation
 : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì} {P : Type ‚Ñì}
 ‚Üí isProp P
 -----------
 ‚Üí (¬¨ (¬¨ P)) ‚Üí P

law-double-negation iP with LEM iP
law-double-negation iP | inl x = Œª _ ‚Üí x
law-double-negation iP | inr x = Œª p‚Üí‚ä•‚Üí‚ä• ‚Üí ‚ä•-elim (p‚Üí‚ä•‚Üí‚ä• x)

Law excluded middle and law of double negation are both equivalent.

Weak extensionality principle:

WeakExtensionalityPrinciple
  : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}  {P : A ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì}
  ‚Üí ((x : A) ‚Üí isContr (P x))
  -------------------------
  ‚Üí isContr ( ‚àè A P )

WeakExtensionalityPrinciple {A = A}{P} f =
  (fx , Œª h ‚Üí  ! funext (Œª x ‚Üí ! (œÄ‚ÇÇ (f x)) (h x)))
  where
   fx : ‚àè A P
   fx = Œª x ‚Üí œÄ‚ÇÅ (f x)

  : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : A ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
  ‚Üí isSet A ‚Üí ((a : A) ‚Üí isSet (B a))
  -------------------
  ‚Üí isSet (Œ£ A B)

  = isProp-‚âÉ
    (pair=Equiv A B)
    (‚àë-prop (iA (œÄ‚ÇÅ x) (œÄ‚ÇÅ y))
      (Œª a ‚Üí f _ (tr (Œª x  ‚Üí B x) a (œÄ‚ÇÇ x)) (œÄ‚ÇÇ y) ))

‚àë-set   = isSet-Œ£

‚âÉ-is-set-from-sets
  : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}

A handy result is that the two point type is a set. We know already that ùüô is indeed mere propositions and hence a set. The two point type ùüö is in fact equivalent to the type ùüô + ùüô. The fact ùüö is a set is used later to show A + B is a set when both are sets.

ùüô-is-set : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} ‚Üí isSet (ùüô ‚Ñì)
ùüô-is-set = prop-is-set (ùüô-is-prop)

ùüô+ùüô-is-set : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} ‚Üí isSet (ùüô ‚Ñì + ùüô ‚Ñì)
ùüô+ùüô-is-set (inl ‚àó) (inl ‚àó) idp idp = idp
ùüô+ùüô-is-set (inr ‚àó) (inr ‚àó) idp idp = idp

ùüö-‚âÉ-ùüô+ùüô
  : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level}
  ‚Üí ùüö ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚âÉ ùüô ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ + ùüô ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ

ùüö-‚âÉ-ùüô+ùüô {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{‚Ñì‚ÇÇ} = quasiinverse-to-‚âÉ f (g ,
  (Œª { (inl x) ‚Üí ap inl idp ; (inr x) ‚Üí ap inr idp}) ,
  Œª { ùüò‚ÇÇ ‚Üí idp ; ùüô‚ÇÇ ‚Üí idp})
  where
    f : ùüö ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Üí ùüô ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ + ùüô ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ
    f ùüò‚ÇÇ = inl ‚àó
    f ùüô‚ÇÇ = inr ‚àó

    g : ùüö ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Üê ùüô ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ + ùüô ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ
    g (inl x) = ùüò‚ÇÇ
    g (inr x) = ùüô‚ÇÇ

ùüö-is-set : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} ‚Üí isSet (ùüö ‚Ñì)
ùüö-is-set {‚Ñì} = ‚âÉ-with-a-set-is-set {‚Ñì}{lsuc ‚Ñì} (‚âÉ-sym (ùüö-‚âÉ-ùüô+ùüô )) ùüô+ùüô-is-set

Another fact we might use later is the fact, natural numbers forms a set. We can see ‚Ñï as a type is equivalent to ‚àë (n : ‚Ñï) ùüô.

The coproduct A + B is equivalent to the sigma type ‚àë ùüö P, where P is the type family that maps ùüò‚ÇÇ to A and consequently, ùüô‚ÇÇ maps to B.

Pùüö-to-A+B
  : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ ‚Ñì‚ÇÉ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
  ‚Üí ùüö ‚Ñì‚ÇÉ ‚Üí Type (‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚äî ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ)
Pùüö-to-A+B {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{‚Ñì‚ÇÇ = ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}{‚Ñì‚ÇÉ}{A}{B} = Œª { ùüò‚ÇÇ ‚Üí ‚Üë ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ A ; ùüô‚ÇÇ ‚Üí ‚Üë ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ B}

+-‚âÉ-‚àë
  : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ ‚Ñì‚ÇÉ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
  ‚Üí A + B ‚âÉ ‚àë (ùüö ‚Ñì‚ÇÉ) (Pùüö-to-A+B {A = A}{B})

+-‚âÉ-‚àë {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}{‚Ñì‚ÇÉ}{A}{B} = quasiinverse-to-‚âÉ f (g
  , (Œª { (ùüò‚ÇÇ , Lift lower‚ÇÅ) ‚Üí idp ; (ùüô‚ÇÇ , Lift lower‚ÇÅ) ‚Üí idp})
  , Œª { (inl x) ‚Üí idp ; (inr x) ‚Üí idp})
  where
  f : A + B ‚Üí ‚àë (ùüö ‚Ñì‚ÇÉ) (Pùüö-to-A+B {A = A}{B})
  f (inl x) = ùüò‚ÇÇ , Lift x
  f (inr x) = ùüô‚ÇÇ , Lift x

  g : A + B ‚Üê ‚àë (ùüö ‚Ñì‚ÇÉ) (Pùüö-to-A+B {A = A}{B})
  g (ùüò‚ÇÇ , Lift a) = inl a
  g (ùüô‚ÇÇ , Lift b) = inr b

+-of-sets-is-set
  : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
  ‚Üí isSet A   ‚Üí isSet B
  ---------------------
  ‚Üí isSet (A + B)

+-of-sets-is-set {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}{A}{B} iA iB
  = ‚âÉ-with-a-set-is-set (‚âÉ-sym (+-‚âÉ-‚àë {‚Ñì‚ÇÉ = ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}{A = A}{B}))
    (‚àë-set ùüö-is-set Œª { ùüò‚ÇÇ ‚Üí fact‚ÇÅ ; ùüô‚ÇÇ ‚Üí fact‚ÇÇ})
  where
  open import BasicEquivalences
  fact‚ÇÅ : isSet (Pùüö-to-A+B {‚Ñì‚ÇÉ = ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}{A = A}{B} ùüò‚ÇÇ)
  fact‚ÇÅ = ‚âÉ-with-a-set-is-set (lifting-equivalence A) iA

  fact‚ÇÇ : isSet (Pùüö-to-A+B {‚Ñì‚ÇÉ = ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}{A = A}{B} ùüô‚ÇÇ)
  fact‚ÇÇ = ‚âÉ-with-a-set-is-set (lifting-equivalence B) iB

‚àë-‚âÉ-base
  : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level}
  ‚Üí {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : A ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
  ‚Üí ((a : A) ‚Üí isContr (B a))
  ---------------------------
  ‚Üí ‚àë A B ‚âÉ A

‚àë-‚âÉ-base {A = A}{B} discrete-base
  = quasiinverse-to-‚âÉ f (g , (H‚ÇÅ , H‚ÇÇ))
  where
  private
   f : ‚àë A B ‚Üí A
   f (a , b) = a

   g : ‚àë A B ‚Üê A
   g a = (a ,  œÄ‚ÇÅ (discrete-base a))

   H‚ÇÅ : f ‚àò g ‚àº id
   H‚ÇÅ x = idp

   H‚ÇÇ : g ‚àò f ‚àº id
   H‚ÇÇ x = pair= (idp , contrIsProp (discrete-base (œÄ‚ÇÅ x)) _ _)

Surjections

  isSurjection
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí (f : A ‚Üí B)
    ‚Üí Type (‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚äî ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ)

  isSurjection {B = B} f = (b : B) ‚Üí ‚à• fib f b ‚à•

  isSurjective = isSurjection
  isOnto       = isSurjection

Do not confuse with the traditional logic notation for surjective functions which says $f$ is surjective if $‚àÄ (b : B) ‚àÉ (a : A) . f a ‚â° b$. This is stronger than merely know exists an $(a : A)$ as it was stated above with ‚à• fib f b ‚à•.

Therefore, we define the concept of split-surjection:

  isSplitSurjection
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí (f : A ‚Üí B)
    ‚Üí Type (‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚äî ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ)

  isSplitSurjection {B = B} f = (b  : B) ‚Üí fib f b

Which is equivalent to say $f$ is a retraction:

  isRetraction
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí (f : A ‚Üí B)
    ‚Üí Type (‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚äî ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ)

  isRetraction {A = A}{B} f =
    ‚àë (B ‚Üí A) (Œª g ‚Üí (b : B) ‚Üí f (g b) ‚â° b)

As a trivial example, we know the identity function is indeed a surjective function. Let us check this.

  identity-is-surjective : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level}{A : Type ‚Ñì} ‚Üí  isSurjection {A = A} id
  identity-is-surjective {A = A} b = ‚à•‚à•-intro (b , idp)

Embeddings

  isEmbedding
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí (f : A ‚Üí B)
    ---------------
    ‚Üí Type (‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚äî ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ)

  isEmbedding {A = A} f = ‚àÄ {x y : A} ‚Üí isEquiv (ap f {x}{y})

Injections

Discuss: should I demand for injective functions have their domains and codomains as sets?

  isInjective
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí (f : A ‚Üí B)
    ‚Üí Type (‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚äî ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ)

  isInjective {A = A} f = ‚àÄ {x y} ‚Üí f x ‚â° f y ‚Üí x ‚â° y

As a trivial example, let us prove identity is an injective function:

  identity-is-injective
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí isInjective {A = A} id

  identity-is-injective p = p

  isInjectiveIsProp
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí (iA : isSet A)
    ‚Üí (f : A ‚Üí B)
    ------------------------
    ‚Üí isProp (isInjective f)

  isInjectiveIsProp {A = A}{B} iA f i1 i2 =
    aux i1 i2
    where
      private
        aux : isProp (‚àÄ {x y} ‚Üí (f x ‚â° f y ‚Üí x ‚â° y))
        aux = pi-is-prop-implicit
               (Œª x ‚Üí pi-is-prop-implicit (Œª y ‚Üí
                 pi-is-prop (Œª p ‚Üí iA x y)
               ))

  injective-is-prop = isInjectiveIsProp

  isSurjectionIsProp
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí (f : A ‚Üí B)
    ‚Üí isProp (isSurjection f)

  isSurjectionIsProp f = pi-is-prop (Œª b ‚Üí truncated-is-prop {A = fib f b})

  surjective-is-prop = isSurjectionIsProp

If the function $f : A ‚Üí B$ is a surjection, we are able to get a function $g : B ‚Üí A$ by the recursion principle of truncation.

  fromSurjection
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí (f : A ‚Üí B)
    ‚Üí isSet B
    ‚Üí isSurjection f
    ‚Üí isInjective f
    --------------------------------
    ‚Üí (b : B) ‚Üí ‚àë A (Œª a ‚Üí f a == b)

  fromSurjection {A = A}{B} f iB f-is-onto f-is-injective b
    = trunc-rec (aux b) id (f-is-onto b)
    where
    private
      aux
        : (b : B)
        ‚Üí isProp (fib f b)

      aux .(f x) (x , idp) (x' , p2) =
        ‚àë-‚â°
          (Œª y ‚Üí f y == f x)
          (f-is-injective (! p2))
          (iB (f x') (f x)
              (tr (Œª z‚ÇÅ ‚Üí f z‚ÇÅ == f x) (f-is-injective (! p2)) idp) p2)

  preimage-function = fromSurjection

Bijections

Bijection is a concept from Set Theory, which meeans that if we want to define it in Univalent Type Theory, we must talk about only functions between (homotopy) sets. Thus, we will find these assumptions in the type for bijections.

  isBijection
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí (f : A ‚Üí B)
    ‚Üí isSet A
    ‚Üí isSet B
    ---------------
    ‚Üí Type (‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚äî ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ)

  isBijection f iA iB = isInjective f √ó isSurjection f

Before to proceed to prove that equivalence and bijection are two logical equivalent concept when we talk about (homotopy) sets, let us give an example of a natural bijection, the idenitity function.

  identity-is-bijection
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí (A-is-set : isSet A)
    ‚Üí isBijection id A-is-set A-is-set

  identity-is-bijection {A} ia = identity-is-injective , identity-is-surjective

Discuss: we again see that the assumption of being a set for the domain is required in the way to check the funciton is injective or surjective. This must suggest, we must include this assumption in the Injective definition.

  Bijection
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí (iA : isSet A) ‚Üí (iB : isSet B)
    ‚Üí (f : A ‚Üí B)
    ‚Üí isBijection f iA iB
    ----------------------
    ‚Üí A ‚âÉ B

  Bijection {A = A}{B} iA iB f (f-is-injective , f-is-onto)
    = qinv-‚âÉ f (g , (H‚ÇÅ , H‚ÇÇ))
    where
    aux : (b : B) ‚Üí ‚àë A (Œª a ‚Üí f a ‚â° b)
    aux = fromSurjection f iB f-is-onto f-is-injective

    g : B ‚Üí A
    g = œÄ‚ÇÅ ‚àò aux

    H‚ÇÅ : (b : B) ‚Üí f (g b) == b
    H‚ÇÅ b = œÄ‚ÇÇ (aux b)

    H‚ÇÇ : (a : A) ‚Üí g (f a) == a
    H‚ÇÇ a = f-is-injective (H‚ÇÅ (f a))

  is-bijection-to-‚âÉ =  Bijection

  ‚âÉ-to-bijection
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí (iA : isSet A)
    ‚Üí (iB : isSet B)
    -----------------------------------------
    ‚Üí (e : A ‚âÉ B) ‚Üí (isBijection (e ‚àô‚Üí) iA iB)

  ‚âÉ-to-bijection iA iB e =
    (Œª {x y} p  ‚Üí ! (‚àô‚Üê‚àò‚àô‚Üí e) ¬∑ (ap (e ‚àô‚Üê) p)  ¬∑ (‚àô‚Üê‚àò‚àô‚Üí e) )  -- is injective
    , Œª b ‚Üí ‚à£ (e ‚àô‚Üê) b , ‚àô‚Üí‚àò‚àô‚Üê e ‚à£                            -- is surjective
    where open import EquivalenceType

Bijection and being equivalent are equivalent notions:

  isBijection-‚âÉ-isEquiv
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí (iA : isSet A) (iB : isSet B)
    ‚Üí (f : A ‚Üí B)
    ----------------------------------
    ‚Üí isBijection f iA iB  ‚âÉ isEquiv f

  isBijection-‚âÉ-isEquiv {A = A}{B} iA iB f =
    qinv-‚âÉ
      (Œª bij ‚Üí œÄ‚ÇÇ (Bijection iA iB f bij))
      ((Œª isEquivf ‚Üí ‚âÉ-to-bijection iA iB (f , isEquivf))
      , h1 , h2)
    where
      h1 : (Œª x ‚Üí œÄ‚ÇÇ (Bijection iA iB f (‚âÉ-to-bijection iA iB (f , x)))) ‚àº id
      h1 e = isContrMapIsProp f _ e

      h2 : (Œª x ‚Üí ‚âÉ-to-bijection iA iB (f , œÄ‚ÇÇ (Bijection iA iB f x))) ‚àº id
      h2 bij = √ó-is-prop (isInjectiveIsProp iA f) (isSurjectionIsProp f) _ bij

  open import QuasiinverseLemmas

  bijIsProp
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí (iA : isSet A)(iB : isSet B)
    ‚Üí (f : A ‚Üí B)
    ------------------------------
    ‚Üí isProp (isBijection f iA iB)

  bijIsProp iA iB f = isProp-‚âÉ (‚âÉ-sym (isBijection-‚âÉ-isEquiv iA iB f)) (isEquivIsProp f)
  bijection-is-prop = bijIsProp

For some reasons, we might need to have the inverse, the actual function, of a bijection. One way I see now is to recover such a function from the equivalence, using remap. Let‚Äôs see this:

  inverse-of-bijection
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí (iA : isSet A) ‚Üí (iB : isSet B)
    ‚Üí (f : A ‚Üí B)
    ‚Üí isBijection f iA iB
    ------------------------------
    ‚Üí B ‚Üí A

  inverse-of-bijection iA iB f isBij
    = remap (Bijection iA iB f isBij)

  inv-of-bij = inverse-of-bijection

  ‚àò-bijective-and-its-inverse-l
      : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
      ‚Üí (A-is-set : isSet A) ‚Üí (B-is-set : isSet B)
      ‚Üí (f : A ‚Üí B) ‚Üí (f-is-bij : isBijection f A-is-set B-is-set)
      --------------------------------------------------------
      ‚Üí f ‚àò inverse-of-bijection A-is-set B-is-set f f-is-bij ‚àº id

  ‚àò-bijective-and-its-inverse-l A-is-set B-is-set f f-is-bij =
    lrmap-inverse-h (is-bijection-to-‚âÉ A-is-set B-is-set f f-is-bij)

  ‚àò-bijective-and-its-inverse-r
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí (A-is-set : isSet A)(B-is-set : isSet B)
    ‚Üí (f : A ‚Üí B) ‚Üí (f-is-bij : isBijection f A-is-set B-is-set)
    ------------------------------------------------------------
    ‚Üí (inverse-of-bijection A-is-set B-is-set f f-is-bij) ‚àò f ‚àº id

  ‚àò-bijective-and-its-inverse-r A-is-set B-is-set f f-is-bij =
    rlmap-inverse-h (is-bijection-to-‚âÉ A-is-set B-is-set f f-is-bij)

The inverse of a bijection is clearly a bijection as well.

  inverse-of-bijection-is-bijection
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level}{A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí (A-is-set : isSet A) ‚Üí (B-is-set : isSet B)
    ‚Üí (f : A ‚Üí B) ‚Üí (f-is-bij : isBijection f A-is-set B-is-set)
    ------------------------------------------------------------
    ‚Üí isBijection (inverse-of-bijection A-is-set B-is-set f f-is-bij) B-is-set A-is-set

  inverse-of-bijection-is-bijection A-is-set B-is-set f f-is-bij
    = inv-f-is-inj , inv-f-is-sur
    where

    inv-f-is-inj : isInjective (inverse-of-bijection A-is-set B-is-set f f-is-bij)
    inv-f-is-inj {x = x}{y} p =
      ! ‚àò-bijective-and-its-inverse-l A-is-set B-is-set f f-is-bij x
      ¬∑  ap f p
      ¬∑ ‚àò-bijective-and-its-inverse-l A-is-set B-is-set f f-is-bij y

    inv-f-is-sur : isSurjection (inverse-of-bijection A-is-set B-is-set f f-is-bij)
    inv-f-is-sur a = ‚à£ f a , ‚àò-bijective-and-its-inverse-r A-is-set B-is-set f f-is-bij a ‚à£

  ‚àò-injectives-is-injective
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ ‚Ñì‚ÇÉ : Level }
    ‚Üí {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ} {B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ} {C : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÉ}
    ‚Üí (f : A ‚Üí B) ‚Üí isInjective f
    ‚Üí (g : B ‚Üí C) ‚Üí isInjective g
    -----------------------------
    ‚Üí isInjective (g ‚àò f)

  ‚àò-injectives-is-injective f f-is-injective g g-is-injective
    p = f-is-injective (g-is-injective p)

As we expect, composition of surjections is also surjections. However, this fact is not trivial and it is a good exercise to understand better propositional truncation.

  ‚àò-surjection-is-surjection
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ ‚Ñì‚ÇÉ : Level }
    ‚Üí {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ} {B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ} {C : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÉ}
    ‚Üí (f : A ‚Üí B) ‚Üí isSurjection f
    ‚Üí (g : B ‚Üí C) ‚Üí isSurjection g
    -----------------------------
    ‚Üí isSurjection (g ‚àò f)

  ‚àò-surjection-is-surjection {A = A}{B}{C} f f-is-surjection g g-is-surjection
    c = step‚ÇÅ (g-is-surjection c)
    where
    step‚ÇÅ : ‚à• ‚àë B (Œª b ‚Üí g b ‚â° c) ‚à• ‚Üí ‚à• ‚àë A (Œª a ‚Üí (f :> g) a ‚â° c) ‚à•
    step‚ÇÅ = trunc-rec ‚à•‚à•-is-a-prop step‚ÇÇ
      where
      step‚ÇÇ : ‚àë B (Œª b ‚Üí g b ‚â° c) ‚Üí ‚à• ‚àë A (Œª a ‚Üí (f :> g) a ‚â° c) ‚à•
      step‚ÇÇ (b , p‚ÇÅ) = step‚ÇÉ b p‚ÇÅ (f-is-surjection b)
        where
        step‚ÇÉ : (b : B) ‚Üí g b ‚â° c
          ‚Üí ‚à• ‚àë A (Œª a ‚Üí f a ‚â° b) ‚à• ‚Üí ‚à• ‚àë A (Œª a ‚Üí (f :> g) a ‚â° c) ‚à•
        step‚ÇÉ b p‚ÇÅ = trunc-rec ‚à•‚à•-is-a-prop step‚ÇÑ
           where
           step‚ÇÑ : ‚àë A (Œª a ‚Üí f a ‚â° b) ‚Üí ‚à• ‚àë A (Œª a ‚Üí (f :> (Œª {a = a‚ÇÅ} ‚Üí g)) a ‚â° c) ‚à•
           step‚ÇÑ (a , p) = ‚à£ a , ((ap g p) ¬∑ p‚ÇÅ) ‚à£

Lastly, bijections is also closed by compositions but its proof is just application of the lemmas proved above. Notice the extra requirement which is the domain and codomains need to be sets. This was not stated above for the related lemmas, but it the condition to talk about the concept of bijection.

  ‚àò-bijections-is-bijection
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ ‚Ñì‚ÇÉ : Level}
    ‚Üí {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}{C : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÉ}
    ‚Üí (A-is-set : isSet A) (B-is-set : isSet B)(C-is-set : isSet C)
    ‚Üí (f : A ‚Üí B) ‚Üí isBijection f A-is-set B-is-set
    ‚Üí (g : B ‚Üí C) ‚Üí isBijection g B-is-set C-is-set
    -----------------------------------------------
    ‚Üí isBijection (g ‚àò f) A-is-set C-is-set

  ‚àò-bijections-is-bijection {A = A}{B}{C}
    A-is-set B-is-set iC
      f (f-is-injective , f-is-surjection)
      g (g-is-injective , g-is-surjection)
    = ‚àò-injectives-is-injective f f-is-injective g g-is-injective
    , ‚àò-surjection-is-surjection f f-is-surjection g g-is-surjection

HedbergLemmas.lagda

layout: page title: ‚ÄúHedberg Lemmas‚Äù toc: true agda: true gallery: true latex: true references: false linkify: true showcitation: true ‚Äî

{-# OPTIONS --without-K #-}
open import TransportLemmas
open import EquivalenceType
open import HLevelTypes
open import RelationType
open import FunExtAxiom
open import FunExtTransport

module
  HedbergLemmas
  where
  module
    HedbergLemmas2
    where

A set is a type satisfiying Axiom K.

    axiomKisSet
      : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}
      ‚Üí ((a : A) ‚Üí (p : a == a) ‚Üí p == refl a)
      ‚Üí isSet A

    axiomKisSet k x _ p idp = k x p

    reflRelIsSet
      : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} (A : Type ‚Ñì)
      ‚Üí (r : Rel A)
      ‚Üí ((x y : A) ‚Üí R  x y ‚Üí x == y)  -- xRy ‚áí Id(x,y)
      ‚Üí   ((x : A) ‚Üí R  x x)           -- ‚àÄ x ‚áí xRx
      ------------------------------------
      ‚Üí isSet A

    reflRelIsSet A r f œÅ x .x p idp = lemma p
      where
      lemma2
        : {a : A}
        ‚Üí (p : a == a) ‚Üí (o : R  a a)
        ‚Üí (f a a o) == f a a (transport (R  a) p o)
                     [ (Œª x ‚Üí a == x) ‚Üì p ]

      lemma2 {a} p = funext-transport-l p (f a a) (f a a) (apd (f a) p)

      lemma3
        :  {a : A}
        ‚Üí (p : a == a)
        ‚Üí (f a a (œÅ a)) ¬∑ p == (f a a (œÅ a))

      lemma3 {a} p = inv (transport-concat-r p _) ¬∑ lemma2 p (œÅ a) ¬∑
                       ap (f a a) (Rprop  a a _ (œÅ a))

      lemma
        : {a : A}
        ‚Üí (p : a == a)
        ‚Üí p == refl a

      lemma {a} p = ¬∑-cancellation ((f a a (œÅ a))) p (lemma3 p)

Lema: if a type is decidable, then ¬¨¬¨A is actually A.

    lemDoubleNeg
      : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}
      ‚Üí (A + ¬¨ A)
      ---------------
      ‚Üí (¬¨ (¬¨ A) ‚Üí A)

    lemDoubleNeg (inl x) _ = x
    lemDoubleNeg (inr f) n = exfalso (n f)

  open HedbergLemmas2 public
  • Hedberg‚Äôs theorem. A type with decidable equality is a set.
  hedberg
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí ((a b : A) ‚Üí (a == b) + ¬¨ (a == b))
    -------------------------------------
    ‚Üí isSet A

  hedberg {‚Ñì}{A = A} f
    = reflRelIsSet A
        (record { R = Œª a b ‚Üí ¬¨ (¬¨ (a == b))
                ; Rprop = isPropNeg })
                doubleNegEq (Œª a z ‚Üí z (refl a))

    where
    doubleNegEq
     : (a b : A) ‚Üí ¬¨ (¬¨ (a == b))
     ‚Üí (a == b)

    doubleNegEq a b p = lemDoubleNeg (f a b) p

    isPropNeg
      : (a b : A)
      ‚Üí isProp (¬¨ (¬¨ (a == b)))

    isPropNeg a b x y = funext Œª u ‚Üí exfalso (x u)

UnivalenceTransport.lagda

layout: page title: ‚ÄúUnivalence Lemmas‚Äù category: lemmas functions homotopy toc: true agda: true gallery: true latex: true references: false linkify: true showcitation: true ‚Äî

{-# OPTIONS --without-K #-}
open import TransportLemmas
open import EquivalenceType

open import HomotopyType
open import FunExtAxiom
open import QuasiinverseType
open import QuasiinverseLemmas


open import UnivalenceAxiom

Transport and Univalence

module UnivalenceTransport where

  transport-family-ap
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}
    ‚Üí (B : A ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ)
    ‚Üí {x y : A}
    ‚Üí (p : x == y)
    ‚Üí (u : B x)
    ---------------------------------------------------
    ‚Üí transport B p u == transport (Œª X ‚Üí X) (ap B p) u

  transport-family-ap B idp u = idp

  transport-family-idtoeqv
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}
    ‚Üí (B : A ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ)
    ‚Üí {x y : A}
    ‚Üí (p : x == y)
    ‚Üí (u : B x)
    ----------------------------------------------
    ‚Üí transport B p u == fun‚âÉ (idtoeqv (ap B p)) u

  transport-family-idtoeqv B idp u = idp

  transport-ua
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}
    ‚Üí (B : A ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ)
    ‚Üí {x y : A}
    ‚Üí (p : x == y)
    ‚Üí (e : B x ‚âÉ B y)
    ‚Üí ap B p == ua e
    -----------------
    ‚Üí (u : B x) ‚Üí transport B p u == (fun‚âÉ e) u

  transport-ua B idp e q u =
    begin
      transport B idp u
        ==‚ü® transport-family-idtoeqv B idp u ‚ü©
      fun‚âÉ (idtoeqv (ap B idp)) u
        ==‚ü® ap (Œª r ‚Üí fun‚âÉ (idtoeqv r) u) q ‚ü©
      fun‚âÉ (idtoeqv (ua e)) u
        ==‚ü® ap (Œª r ‚Üí fun‚âÉ r u) (ua-Œ≤ e) ‚ü©
      fun‚âÉ e u
    ‚àé

  funext-transport-ua
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}
    ‚Üí (B : A ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ)
    ‚Üí {x y : A}
    ‚Üí (p : x == y)
    ‚Üí (e : B x ‚âÉ B y)
    ‚Üí ap B p == ua e
    -----------------
    ‚Üí transport B p == (fun‚âÉ e)

  funext-transport-ua B p e x‚ÇÅ = funext (transport-ua B p e x‚ÇÅ)

  coe-ua
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A B : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí (Œ± : A ‚âÉ B)
    -------------------------------------
    ‚Üí (‚àÄ x ‚Üí (coe (ua Œ±) x) == ((Œ± ‚àô) x))

  coe-ua Œ± = happly (ap (lemap) (ua-Œ≤ Œ±))

  coe-ua-¬∑
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A B C : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí (Œ± : A ‚âÉ B)
    ‚Üí (Œ≤ : B ‚âÉ C)
    --------------------------------------------------
    ‚Üí coe (ua Œ± ¬∑ ua Œ≤) ‚â° ((coe (ua Œ±)) :> coe (ua Œ≤))

  coe-ua-¬∑ Œ± Œ≤ =
    begin
      coe (ua Œ± ¬∑ ua Œ≤)
       ‚â°‚ü®‚ü©
      tr (Œª X ‚Üí X) (ua Œ± ¬∑ ua Œ≤)
       ‚â°‚ü® ! (transport-comp (ua Œ±) (ua Œ≤)) ‚ü©
      (tr (Œª X ‚Üí X) (ua Œ±)) :> (tr (Œª X ‚Üí X) (ua Œ≤))
        ‚â°‚ü® idp ‚ü©
     ((coe (ua Œ±)) :> coe (ua Œ≤))
    ‚àé

In addition, we can state a similar result with idtoequiv:

  idtoequiv-ua-¬∑
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A B C : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí (Œ± : A ‚âÉ B)
    ‚Üí (Œ≤ : B ‚âÉ C)
    ---------------------------------------------------
    ‚Üí ite (ua Œ± ¬∑ ua Œ≤) ‚â° ((ite (ua Œ±)) ‚àò‚âÉ (ite (ua Œ≤)))

  idtoequiv-ua-¬∑ Œ± Œ≤ = sameEqv (coe-ua-¬∑ Œ± Œ≤)
    where open import HLevelLemmas

  ite-ua-¬∑ = idtoequiv-ua-¬∑

  postulate
   ‚àò‚âÉ-ite-ua
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A B C : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí (Œ± : A ‚âÉ B)
    ‚Üí (Œ≤ : B ‚âÉ C)
    ‚Üí (Œ± ‚àò‚âÉ Œ≤) ‚â° ite (ua Œ± ¬∑ ua Œ≤)

  {- lemma Œ± Œ≤ =
        begin
          (Œ± ‚àò‚âÉ Œ≤)
            ‚â°‚ü® ap‚ÇÇ (Œª x y ‚Üí x ‚àò‚âÉ y) (! (ua-Œ≤ Œ±)) (! (ua-Œ≤ Œ≤)) ‚ü©
          (ite (ua Œ±)) ‚àò‚âÉ (ite (ua Œ≤))
            ‚â°‚ü® ! (ite-ua-¬∑ Œ± Œ≤) ‚ü©
          ite (ua Œ± ¬∑ ua Œ≤)
  -}

Univalence Lemma for id Equivalence

module UnivalenceIdEquiv where

The identity equivalence creates the trivial path.

  ua-id
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}
    --------------------
    ‚Üí ua idEqv ‚â° refl A

  ua-id {A = A} =
    begin
      ua idEqv
        ‚â°‚ü® ap ua (sameEqv (refl id)) ‚ü©
      ua (idtoeqv (refl A))
        ‚â°‚ü® ua-Œ∑ (refl A) ‚ü©
      refl A
    ‚àé

Univalence lemmas

module UnivalenceComposition where

  ua-comp
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A B C : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí (Œ± : A ‚âÉ B)
    ‚Üí (Œ≤ : B ‚âÉ C)
    ---------------------------------
    ‚Üí ua (Œ± ‚àò‚âÉ Œ≤) == (ua Œ±) ¬∑ (ua Œ≤)

  ua-comp Œ± Œ≤  =
   begin
     ua (Œ± ‚àò‚âÉ Œ≤)
       ‚â°‚ü® ap ua (‚àò‚âÉ-ite-ua Œ± Œ≤) ‚ü©
     ua (ite (ua Œ± ¬∑ ua Œ≤))
       ‚â°‚ü® ua-Œ∑ ((ua Œ±) ¬∑ (ua Œ≤)) ‚ü©
     (ua Œ±) ¬∑ (ua Œ≤)
   ‚àé

Inverses are preserved (Type-check this takes ~30min)

  postulate
   ua-inv-r
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A B : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí (Œ± : A ‚âÉ B)
    -------------------------------
    ‚Üí ua Œ± ¬∑ ua (‚âÉ-sym Œ±) == refl A

  {-
  ua-inv-r {A = A} Œ± =
    begin
      ua Œ± ¬∑ ua (‚âÉ-sym Œ±)
        ==‚ü® ! (ua-comp Œ± (‚âÉ-sym Œ±)) ‚ü©
      ua (‚âÉ-trans Œ± (‚âÉ-sym Œ±))
        ==‚ü® ap ua (‚âÉ-trans-inv Œ±) ‚ü©
      ua idEqv
        ==‚ü® UnivalenceLemmas.ua-id ‚ü©
      refl A
    ‚àé
  -}

  ua-inv
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A B : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí (Œ± : A ‚âÉ B)
    -------------------------
    ‚Üí ua (‚âÉ-sym Œ±) ‚â° ! (ua Œ±)

  ua-inv Œ± =
    begin
      ua (‚âÉ-sym Œ±)
        ‚â°‚ü® ap (_¬∑ ua (‚âÉ-sym Œ±)) (! (¬∑-linv (ua Œ±))) ‚ü©
      ! (ua Œ±) ¬∑ ua Œ± ¬∑ ua (‚âÉ-sym Œ±)
        ‚â°‚ü® ¬∑-assoc (! (ua Œ±)) _ _ ‚ü©
      ! (ua Œ±) ¬∑ (ua Œ± ¬∑ ua (‚âÉ-sym Œ±))
        ‚â°‚ü® ap (! (ua Œ±) ¬∑_) (ua-inv-r Œ±) ‚ü©
      ! (ua Œ±) ¬∑ refl _
        ‚â°‚ü® ! (¬∑-runit (! ((ua Œ±)))) ‚ü©
      ! (ua Œ±)
    ‚àé

Circles

The circle type is constructed by postulating a type with a single element (base) and a nontrivial path (loop).

module CircleType where

  private
    data !S¬π : Type‚ÇÄ where
      !base : !S¬π

  S¬π : Type‚ÇÄ
  S¬π = !S¬π

  base : S¬π
  base = !base

  postulate
    loop : base == base

Recursion principle on points

  S¬π-rec
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} (A : Type ‚Ñì)
    ‚Üí (a : A)
    ‚Üí (p : a == a)
    --------------
    ‚Üí (S¬π ‚Üí A)

  S¬π-rec A a p !base = a

Recursion principle on paths

  postulate
    S¬π-Œ≤rec
      : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} (A : Type ‚Ñì)
      ‚Üí (a : A)
      ‚Üí (p : a == a)
      ------------------------------
      ‚Üí ap (S¬π-rec A a p) loop == p

Induction principle on points

  S¬π-ind
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level}(P : S¬π ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì)
    ‚Üí (x : P base)
    ‚Üí (x == x [ P ‚Üì loop ])
    --------------------------
    ‚Üí ((t : S¬π) ‚Üí P t)

  S¬π-ind P x p !base = x

Induction principle on paths

  postulate
    S¬π-Œ≤ind
      : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} (P : S¬π ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì)
      ‚Üí (x : P base)
      ‚Üí (p : x == x [ P ‚Üì loop ])
      -------------------------------
      ‚Üí apd (S¬π-ind P x p) loop == p

Intervals

Interval. An interval is defined by taking two points (two elements) and a path between them (an element of the equality type). This path is nontrivial.

module IntervalType where

  private

    data !I : Type‚ÇÄ where
      !Izero : !I
      !Ione : !I

  I : Type‚ÇÄ
  I = !I

  Izero : I
  Izero = !Izero

  Ione : I
  Ione = !Ione

  postulate
    seg : Izero == Ione

Recursion principle on points.

  I-rec
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí (a b : A)
    ‚Üí (p : a == b)
    --------------
    ‚Üí (I ‚Üí A)

  I-rec a _ _ !Izero = a
  I-rec _ b _ !Ione  = b

Recursion principle on paths.

  postulate
    I-Œ≤rec
      : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} (A : Type ‚Ñì)
      ‚Üí (a b : A)
      ‚Üí (p : a == b)
      ---------------------------
      ‚Üí ap (I-rec a b p) seg == p

Suspensions

module SuspensionType where

  module S where

  private
    data Susp‚Çö {‚Ñì : Level} (A : Type ‚Ñì) : Type ‚Ñì where
      N‚Çö : Susp‚Çö A
      S‚Çö : Susp‚Çö A

    data Susp‚Çì {‚Ñì} (A : Type ‚Ñì) : Type ‚Ñì where
      mkSusp : Susp‚Çö A ‚Üí (ùüô ‚Ñì ‚Üí ùüô ‚Ñì) ‚Üí Susp‚Çì A

  Susp = Susp‚Çì

  -- point-constructors
  North : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì} {A : Type ‚Ñì} ‚Üí Susp A
  North = mkSusp N‚Çö _

  South : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì} {A : Type ‚Ñì} ‚Üí Susp A
  South = mkSusp S‚Çö _

  -- path-constructors
  postulate
    merid : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì} {A : Type ‚Ñì}
          ‚Üí A
          ‚Üí Path {‚Ñì}{Susp A} North South

Recursion principle on points

  Susp-rec
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{C : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí (c‚Çô c‚Çõ  : C)
    ‚Üí (merid' : A ‚Üí c‚Çô == c‚Çõ)
    ------------------------
    ‚Üí (Susp A ‚Üí C)

  Susp-rec c‚Çô _ _ (mkSusp N‚Çö _) = c‚Çô
  Susp-rec _ c‚Çõ _ (mkSusp S‚Çö _) = c‚Çõ

Recursion principle on paths

  postulate
    Susp-Œ≤rec
      : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{C : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
      ‚Üí {c‚Çô c‚Çõ : C} {mer : A ‚Üí c‚Çô == c‚Çõ}
      ‚Üí {a : A}
      -------------------------------------------
      ‚Üí ap (Susp-rec c‚Çô c‚Çõ mer) (merid a) == mer a

Induction principle on points

  Susp-ind
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì} (C : Susp A ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì)
    ‚Üí (N' : C North)
    ‚Üí (S' : C South)
    ‚Üí (merid' : (x : A) ‚Üí N' == S' [ C ‚Üì (merid x) ])
    --------------------------------------------------
    ‚Üí ((x : Susp A) ‚Üí C x)

  Susp-ind _ N' S' _ (mkSusp N‚Çö _) = N'
  Susp-ind _ N' S' _ (mkSusp S‚Çö _) = S'

Induction principle on paths

  postulate
    Susp-Œ≤ind
      : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì} {A : Type ‚Ñì} (C : Susp A ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì)
      ‚Üí (N' : C North)
      ‚Üí (S' : C South)
      ‚Üí (merid' : (x : A) ‚Üí N' == S' [ C ‚Üì (merid x)]) {x : A}
      --------------------------------------------------------
      ‚Üí apd (Susp-ind C N' S' merid') (merid x) == merid' x

Propositional truncation

Propositional truncation (or reflection) is the universal solution to the problem of mapping $X$ to a proposition $P$:

X  ‚Üí ‚à• X ‚à•
 ‚Üò    ‚á£ (!‚àÉ h)
    ‚Üò P

Notes:

  • It‚Äôs possible to extend MLTT to get truncations for all types. (Such as resizing + funext, or higher inductive types.)

For a different way of formalising trucation see: agd-premises.

module
  TruncationType
  where

  private
    data
      !‚à•_‚à• {‚Ñì} (A : Type ‚Ñì)
        : Type ‚Ñì
        where
        !‚à£_‚à£ : A ‚Üí !‚à• A ‚à•

  ‚à•_‚à•
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} (A : Type ‚Ñì)
    ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì

  ‚à• A ‚à• = !‚à• A ‚à•

  prop-trunc = ‚à•_‚à•

  ‚à£_‚à£
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {X : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí X
    ‚Üí ‚à• X ‚à•

  ‚à£ x ‚à£ = !‚à£ x ‚à£

  ‚à•‚à•-intro = ‚à£_‚à£

Any two elements of the truncated type are equal

  postulate
    trunc
      : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}
      ‚Üí isProp ‚à• A ‚à•

Recursion principle

  trunc-rec
    :  ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{P : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí isProp P
    ‚Üí (A ‚Üí P)
    ---------
    ‚Üí ‚à• A ‚à• ‚Üí P

  trunc-rec _ f !‚à£ x ‚à£ = f x

  trunc-elim = trunc-rec
  ‚à•‚à•-rec     = trunc-rec

There exists the possibility to charactherize, propositional truncation using an impredicative approach, which means, our definition will lay on a larger universe as follows on the right-hand side.

Remarks:

  • rhs is a propositon assuming funext
  • this equation tells us an important relation (a pattern) between the type (in this case, prop-trunc) and its elimination principle (trunc-rec)
  • Impredicative means in this context: ‚Äúit is defined in terms of quantification over a family which the thing we are defining is a member of.‚Äù (Gylterud).

Truncation Lemmas

  truncated-is-prop
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí isProp (‚à• A ‚à•)
  truncated-is-prop = trunc

  ‚à•‚à•-is-a-prop = truncated-is-prop

  prop-‚âÉ-truncated
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí isProp A
    ‚Üí ‚à• A ‚à• ‚âÉ A

  prop-‚âÉ-truncated pA = lemma333 trunc pA (trunc-rec pA id) ‚à£_‚à£

  trunc-‚âÉ = prop-‚âÉ-truncated

A relation between double implication and the truncation of a type:

  postulate
   trunc-‚áî-¬¨¬¨
     : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì} {X : Type ‚Ñì}
     ‚Üí ‚à• X ‚à• ‚áî (¬¨ (¬¨ X))

Set truncations

module SetTruncationType where

  private
    -- Higher inductive type
    data !‚à•_‚à•‚ÇÄ {‚Ñì} (A : Type ‚Ñì) : Type ‚Ñì where
      !‚à£_‚à£‚ÇÄ : A ‚Üí !‚à• A ‚à•‚ÇÄ

  ‚à•_‚à•‚ÇÄ
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} (A : Type ‚Ñì)
    ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì

  ‚à• A ‚à•‚ÇÄ = !‚à• A ‚à•‚ÇÄ

  ‚à£_‚à£‚ÇÄ
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {X : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí X
    ‚Üí ‚à• X ‚à•‚ÇÄ

  ‚à£ x ‚à£‚ÇÄ = !‚à£ x ‚à£‚ÇÄ

  postulate
    strunc
      : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}
      ‚Üí isSet ‚à• A ‚à•‚ÇÄ

Recursion principle

  strunc-rec
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}{P : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí isSet P
    ‚Üí (A ‚Üí P)
    ------------
    ‚Üí ‚à• A ‚à•‚ÇÄ ‚Üí P

  strunc-rec _ f !‚à£ x ‚à£‚ÇÄ = f x

Induction principle

  strunc-ind
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ} {B : ‚à• A ‚à•‚ÇÄ ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí ((a : ‚à• A ‚à•‚ÇÄ) ‚Üí isSet (B a))
    ‚Üí (g : (a : A) ‚Üí B ‚à£ a ‚à£‚ÇÄ)
    ------------------------------
    ‚Üí (a : ‚à• A ‚à•‚ÇÄ) ‚Üí B a

  strunc-ind _ g !‚à£ x ‚à£‚ÇÄ = g x

QuotientType.lagda

open import HedbergLemmas

module QuotientType where

  record QRel {‚Ñì : Level} (A : Type ‚Ñì) : Type (lsuc ‚Ñì) where
    field
      R     : A ‚Üí A ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì
      Aset  : isSet A
      Rprop : (a b : A) ‚Üí isProp (R a b)

  open QRel  public

  private
    data _!/_ {‚Ñì : Level} (A : Type ‚Ñì)  (r : QRel A)
      : Type (lsuc ‚Ñì)
      where
      ![_] : A ‚Üí (A !/ r)

  _/_
    : {‚Ñì : Level} (A : Type ‚Ñì)  (r : QRel A)
    ‚Üí Type (lsuc ‚Ñì)

  A / r = (A !/ r)

  [_]
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí A ‚Üí {r : QRel A}
    ---------
    ‚Üí (A / r)

  [ a ] = ![ a ]

  -- Equalities induced by the relation
  postulate
    Req
      : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}  {r : QRel A}
      ‚Üí {a b : A}
      ‚Üí R  a b
      --------------------
      ‚Üí [ a ] {r} == [ b ]

  -- The quotient of a set is again a set
  postulate
    Rtrunc
      : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì}  {r : QRel A}
      ---------------
      ‚Üí isSet (A / r)

Recursion principle

  QRel-rec
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ}  {r : QRel A} {B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí (f : A ‚Üí B)
    ‚Üí ((x y : A) ‚Üí R  x y ‚Üí f x == f y)
    ---------------------------------------
    ‚Üí A / r ‚Üí B

  QRel-rec f p ![ x ] = f x

Induction principle

  QRel-ind
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level} {A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ} {r : QRel A} {B : A / r ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí (f : ((a : A) ‚Üí B [ a ]))
    ‚Üí ((x y : A) ‚Üí (o : R  x y) ‚Üí (transport B (Req o) (f x)) == f y)
    -------------------
    ‚Üí (z : A / r) ‚Üí B z

  QRel-ind f p ![ x ] = f x

Recursion in two arguments

  QRel-rec-bi
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ : Level}{A : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ} {r : QRel A} {B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ}
    ‚Üí (f : A ‚Üí A ‚Üí B)
    ‚Üí ((x y z t : A) ‚Üí R  x y ‚Üí R  z t ‚Üí f x z == f y t)
    -------------------
    ‚Üí A / r ‚Üí A / r ‚Üí B

  QRel-rec-bi f p ![ x ] ![ y ] = f x y

  Qrel-prod
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level}{A : Type ‚Ñì}
    ‚Üí (r : QRel A)
    --------------
    ‚Üí QRel (A √ó A)

  Qrel-prod r =
    record { R = Œª { (a , b) (c , d) ‚Üí (R  a c) √ó (R  b d) }
           ; Aset = isSet-prod (Aset ) (Aset )
           ; Rprop = Œª { (x , y) (q , w) ‚Üí isProp-prod (Rprop  x q) (Rprop  y w)} }

    field

  open Rel  public

Monoids

A monoid is a algebraic structure on a set with a featured object called the unit and an associative binary operation (also called the multiplication) that fulfills certain properties described below.

Before monoids, we could define instead a much simpler structure, the magma. A magma is basically a set and an binary operation. Then, any monoid is also magma, but magmas are not so interesting as the monoids.

module
  MonoidType
    where

  record
    Monoid {‚Ñì : Level}
      : Type (lsuc ‚Ñì)
      where
    constructor monoid
    field
      M   : Type ‚Ñì       -- The carrier
      e   : M            -- Unit element (at least one element, this one)
      _‚äï_ : M ‚Üí M ‚Üí M    -- Operation

      M-is-set : isSet M   -- the carrier is a set

      -- axioms:
      l-unit : (x : M) ‚Üí (e ‚äï x) == x
      r-unit : (x : M) ‚Üí (x ‚äï e) == x
      assoc  : (x y z : M) ‚Üí (x ‚äï (y ‚äï z)) == ((x ‚äï y) ‚äï z)

  GroupType

A group $G$ is a monoid with something else, inverses for each element. This means, there is a function $\mathsf{inverse} : G ‚Üí G$ such that:

where $G$ is the group, $e$ the unit and $<>$ the operation from the underlined monoid. This is the following type for groups:

  Group
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} ‚Üí Type (lsuc ‚Ñì)

  Group
    = ‚àë (Monoid) (Œª {(monoid G e _<>_ GisSet lunit runit assoc)
      ‚Üí ‚àë (G ‚Üí G) (Œª inverse ‚Üí
        ‚àè G (Œª x ‚Üí
          -- properties:
          (   (x <> inverse x) == e)
          √ó ( (inverse x <> x) == e ))
          )})

Fundamental group

Definition of the fundamental group of a type. Let a:A be one point of the type. The fundamental group on a is the group given by proofs of the equality (a=a).

module FundamentalGroupType where

Definition of the fundamental group.

  Œ©
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level}(A : Type ‚Ñì)
    ------------------
    ‚Üí (a : A) ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì

  Œ© A a = (a == a)

  Œ©-gr
    : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì : Level} (A : Type ‚Ñì)
    ‚Üí (a : A) ‚Üí Group {‚Ñì}
  Œ©-gr A a =
    monoid
      (Œ© A a)
      (refl a)
      _¬∑_
      (Œª x y p q ‚Üí _)
      (Œª (x : Œ© A a) ‚Üí refl x)
      (Œª (x : Œ© A a) ‚Üí ! (¬∑-runit x))
      (Œª x y z ‚Üí ! (¬∑-assoc x y z)  )
    , inv , Œª x ‚Üí ¬∑-rinv x , ¬∑-linv x
    where open import MonoidType

The Axiom Of Choice

module
  TheAxiomOfChoice
  where

Let‚Äôs write in type theory, the following logic formulation of of the axiom of choice:

  postulate
    Choice
      : ‚àÄ {‚Ñì‚ÇÅ ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ ‚Ñì‚ÇÉ : Level }
      -- Asummption 1:
        (B : Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÅ)
      ‚Üí isSet B
      -- Asummption 2:
      ‚Üí (A : B ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÇ)
      ‚Üí ‚àÄ (b : B) ‚Üí isSet (A b)
      -- Asummption 3:
      ‚Üí (P : (b : B) ‚Üí (A b) ‚Üí Type ‚Ñì‚ÇÉ)
      ‚Üí ‚àÄ (b : B)(a : A b) ‚Üí isProp (P b a)
      -----------------------------------
      ‚Üí (‚àÄ b ‚Üí ‚à• ‚àë (A b) (Œª a ‚Üí P b a) ‚à•)
      ‚Üí ‚à• ‚àë (‚àè B A) (Œª g ‚Üí P b (g b)) ‚à•
